message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: draft Translator's Preface now or after?">
The author asks: should the translator write a draft of the Translator's Preface NOW (before full translation begins) to capture all the decisions while they're fresh — with the understanding it will be revised after translation is complete? Or should we wait until after?

Reply "NOW" or "AFTER" with a brief reason.
</teammate-message>

input.content: NOW — The decisions that need to be captured are at peak clarity right now: the 境-family system, the 德 split convention, the 形/现象 reinterpretation, the five registers, the philosophical experiment warning, all seven Q-file resolutions, and the cross-expert consensus points. These are complex, interconnected decisions that will be harder to reconstruct after months of translation work. A draft now serves as a working document that guides the translation itself — the translator can refer back to it for tone, framing, and priorities. It will certainly need revision after translation (some decisions may evolve, the translator will discover new issues), but revising a draft is far easier than writing from scratch with faded memory. This is the epistemological point the author's own framework makes: knowledge is processual, and capturing the current state of the knowledge network preserves structure that would otherwise be lost to evolution.
input.summary: NOW — capture decisions at peak clarity, revise later
